Based on the search results, I found comprehensive information about Polish theatrical adaptations and film/television adaptations of "Wichrowe Wzgórza" (Wuthering Heights). Here's what I discovered:

## Polish Theater Productions

The novel "Wichrowe Wzgórza" was staged for the first time on a Polish stage at Teatr Studio in Warsaw. The adaptation was created by young playwright Julia Holewińska, winner of the Gdynia Dramatic Award in 2010 for her play "Ciała obce".

The creators attempted to approach "Wichrowe Wzgórza" as a kind of "encyclopedia of love", exploring various forms of relationships from sibling bonds to parental love and ultimately romantic relationships.

The production took a modern approach by translating the romantic novel into contemporary language, omitting the Victorian setting. The modern adaptation included references to Marlon Brando, branded tea, and football fans' chants.

## Film and Television Adaptations

The novel has been adapted numerous times into films, television productions, and miniseries. The first film adaptation was made in 1920 as a silent film covering the entire novel, though it is now lost.

Research has analyzed several major film adaptations, including versions directed by Peter Kosminsky (USA-UK, 1992) and Andrea Arnold (UK, 2011).

Currently, there's a Turkish television series adaptation called "Wichrowe wzgórze" available on TVP VOD, following characters Zeynep and Halil, with Halil returning to the city to avenge his family who were unjustly accused and lost their fortune.

## Cultural Impact

The novel's first Polish publication was in 1929 under the title "Szatańska miłość" (Satanic Love), translated by Janika Sujkowska. The early Polish edition carried the title "Szatańska miłość," while critics who were scandalized by the novel suggested calling it "Obmierzłe wzgórza" (Loathsome Heights).

The novel continues to resonate because it addresses timeless issues such as ethnic prejudice, power struggles, the importance of wealth and origin in marriage decisions, and double moral standards.
